p: Future projections of sea-level rise (SLR) are deeply uncertain [ 12– 14]. Deep uncertainty in this context means that, “the suite of all possible future events as well as their associated probability distributions are … uncertain,” [ 15]. Sea-level projections are deeply uncertain because of the complex mechanisms controlling changes in sea level (i.e., thermal expansion of water, inputs from glaciers and ice sheets, changes in land water storage, glacial isostatic adjustment, vertical land motion from tectonics, and coastal erosion) [ 1, 16].
